title: Inside Turkey's President Erdogan's rise to power
text:

Donald Trump went to Istanbul in 2012 for the opening of the Trump Towers complex.

The guest of honour was Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the country’s then Prime Minister, now the President.

Trump, in between plugging the US version of The Apprentice, heaped praise on Erdogan.

He said: “The Prime Minister is very highly respected.”

Last week Trump did Erdogan another favour by withdrawing US troops from northern Syria where they were helping Kurdish forces contain the Islamic State threat.

The US President effectively gave Erdogan the green light to launch an invasion, he calls it a “peace operation”, aimed at forcing out the Kurds from the region.

What happens next could determine the fate of the Middle East and could redraw the battle lines in the power struggle between Russia and the West.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Erdogan is standing over a powder keg with a lit torch.

When the EU protested at his military incursion he threatened to send into Europe the 3.6 million Syrian refugees Brussels has paid Turkey £5.25billion to look after.

At the UN last month he lectured other nations about the refugees as he held a photo of Alan Kurdi, the three-year-old Syrian boy whose body washed ashore in Turkey in 2015 after drowning trying to cross the Mediterranean.

Nor does he appear to care that the Kurdish Syrian Democratic Forces are being driven into the arms of Syria’s dictator Bashar al-Assad.

The Turkish president has never been afraid of making enemies. Which may be just as well as he is about to make a lot more of them.

Born in 1954, the son of a coastguard, he supplemented the family’s meagre income by selling lemonade on Istanbul’s streets.

After attending Islamic School he did a degree in business management before taking his first steps into politics.

In the 1970s he joined the Islamist National Salvation Party, challenging the secular tradition that had been the hallmark of Turkey since Mustafa Kemal Ataturk’s presidency in the 1920s.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

When Erdogan was banned from taking his seat in parliament in 1991 he successfully stood to be Mayor of Istanbul in 1994.

In 1999 he was jailed for four months for reading out an Islamist poem that included the lines “the mosques are our barracks, the domes our helmets, the minarets our bayonets and the faithful our soldiers.”

Two years later he founded the Justice and Development Party (AKP) which swept to power in 2002 with Erdogan as Prime Minister.

His initial years in power saw him reach out to a West that was, in those days, still hoping that Turkey could one day join the EU.

Critics of his tendency to accumulate power and silence critics were won over by his economic reforms and technocratic flair.

But it became increasingly hard to ignore his authoritarian tendencies.

In 2014 he became the country’s first directly-elected president.

Then in 2016 he used the aborted military coup to impose a state of emergency that saw him throttle dissent and imprison opponents.

He then held a referendum in 2017 to grant himself more powers.

Erdogan abolished the post of Prime Minister and gave himself the right to appoint ministers and senior civil servants, issue decrees and oversee all security matters.

(Image: Anadolu Agency via Getty Images)

The United Nations Human Rights Office said the scale of the repression was “staggering”.

In the past three years nearly 160,000 people have been arrested; 152,000 civil servants sacked; teachers, judges and lawyers prosecuted on trumped-up charges; 300 journalists arrested; 100,000 websites blocked and 180 media outlets shut down.

Like Trump he is not adverse to large scale building projects, though his recently completed presidential palace in Ankara makes Trump Towers look like an exhibit from LegoLand.

The building cost £476million and has more than 1,000 rooms, including a laboratory where scientists can check the president’s food has not been poisoned.

In the first sign that Erdogan’s grip on power may be fading, his party lost the Istanbul elections in March.

After ordering a re-run on the unproven charges of vote rigging he was defeated again with the Republican People’s Party winning by an even bigger margin.

The economy has also begun to slow with unemployment reaching 15% and inflation nudging 20%.

His invasion of northern Syria is seen by some as a classic example of a leader using a military exercise to distract attention from domestic failings.

Having won power as a nationalist hard man, Erdogan would have looked weak if he failed to move against Kurds he has long accused of being terrorists.

The brutality witnessed on the domestic front has now extended to the foreign.

Airstrikes on Kurdish territory by Turkey forces have killed innocent children and caused thousands of civilians to flee the area.

Any chance of Turkey joining the EU has evaporated because of Erdogan’s autocratic rule.

This has pushed the Turkish leader closer towards Vladimir Putin.

(Image: MAXIM SHIPENKOV/POOL/EPA-EFE/REX)

The growing ties with Russia were underlined by the recent purchase of Russian S-400 missiles, a move which raised fresh questions about Turkey’s NATO membership.

But Erdogan is playing a dangerous game with his incursion into Northern Syria.

Several Arab states have condemned the move amid fears it could upset the delicate balance of power in the region and lead to a revival of ISIS.

The nightmare outcome is a war between Turkey and the Syrian Democratic Forces now allied with Assad and supported with Russian firepower.

In such a scenario would NATO fulfil its duty to support an ally in all circumstances?

Tom Tugenhat MP, who chairs the Commons Foreign Affairs committee, says Putin could emerge as the main winner with Assad tightening his grip on Syria and the solidarity of NATO undermined.

“America pulling out was a display of weakness. The danger now is Russia wins either way,” he said.

Whether Turkey wins is another matter.

Erdogan risks turning a country that wanted to be the friends of the East and the West into a pariah state.
description: The political career of Recep Tayyip Erdogan goes a long way to explain his country's latest invasion of Syria
